content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> Jake Archibald: sideshowbarker: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1330 might be of interest

Thanks for the heads-up about that. I think it‚Äôs a great addition that‚Äôll be quite helpful ‚Äî but I took the opportunity to suggest we consider dropping the existing statement that encourages sending 403 errors for the ‚Äúopting out of CORS‚Äù case.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
Jake Archibald: sideshowbarker: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1330 might be of interest
Thanks for the heads-up about that. I think it‚Äôs a great addition that‚Äôll be quite helpful ‚Äî but I took the opportunity to suggest we consider dropping the existing statement that encourages sending 403 errors for the ‚Äúopting out of CORS‚Äù case.

content.body: and  don‚Äôt think anybody mentioned https://jakearchibald.com/2021/cors/ here yet, but everybody who cares anything about CORS should really read that

annevk: I think I found a good solution for the race-condition thingy (https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1311/files). Using existing queues for synchronization instead of introducing atomic lingo. Hope this works :)
content.formatted_body: annevk: I think I found a good solution for the race-condition thingy (https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1311/files). Using existing queues for synchronization instead of introducing atomic lingo. Hope this works :)

content.body: Jake Archibald: By the way, about CORS pain points for developers, from what I‚Äôve observed in the thousands of Stack Overflow CORS questions I‚Äôve read, by far the single biggest pain point is that developers see a CORS error get logged in the devtools console and assume the cause is some problem with the CORS config on the server side ‚Äî when in fact, the real problem is that the response is 400 or 500 error or other 4xx/5xx error
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: By the way, about CORS pain points for developers, from what I‚Äôve observed in the thousands of Stack Overflow CORS questions I‚Äôve read, by far the single biggest pain point is that developers see a CORS error get logged in the devtools console and assume the cause is some problem with the CORS config on the server side ‚Äî when in fact, the real problem is that the response is 400 or 500 error or other 4xx/5xx error

content.body: but, browsers don‚Äôt log those 4xx/5xx errors to the devtools console, so all that the developers see is the CORS error
so they reasonably assume the cause is some CORS-config issue, and then each of those developers spends literally hours trying to figure out what they got wrong in their CORS config

I've now tweaked https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/7205 after reading it again after sleeping overnight between writing and reading. It could use spec-ese review. In particular, review of how the tree builder parts connect by reference to metaParser instead of minting a new concept for the thing that metaParser is.
I integrated the byte pattern analysis bits in this changeset, because it seemed silly not to.
The byte pattern analysis bits are intentionally vague enough to permit what Chrome does.

Jake Archibald:  and multiply that by probably at least some hundreds of developers (but maybe even more like thousands) every day who go through that dance, and the result is a massive amount of time we are causing developers to waste by leading them to chase after problems in the wrong place
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: and multiply that by probably at least some hundreds of developers (but maybe even more like thousands) every day who go through that dance, and the result is a massive amount of time we are causing developers to waste by leading them to chase after problems in the wrong place

content.body: If the server gives a 4xx or a 5xx to a preflight, that does indicate there's a server issue though.
Depends if you count 404 as a server issue
And if it gives it to a non-preflight, but doesn't include the necessary CORS headers, that could be a server issue, depending on whether they want to partake.
Jake Archibald: I was assuming the request was made correctly.
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: I was assuming the request was made correctly.

content.body: I think the cases sideshowbarker is referring to involves an incorrect request, but the CORS error makes it look like an incorrect response.
content.formatted_body: I think the cases sideshowbarker is referring to involves an incorrect request, but the CORS error makes it look like an incorrect response.

content.body: Kinda funny that if you want the page to get access to a 404, the prelight needs to return a not-404
I don't have a better idea though
(other than ignoring the status code)

by thy way, for *‚ÄúAccess to 'foo' from origin 'bar' has been blocked by CORS policy: Response to preflight request doesn't pass access control check: It does not have HTTP ok status‚Äù*, I don‚Äôt understand why that message doesn‚Äôt have ‚ÄúThe HTTP status was 4xx‚Äù ‚Äî that is, just make that message show the actual status code, rather than *‚Äúdoes not have HTTP ok status‚Äù*. Knowing the actual status code there would be way more helpful to developers. It would cut out the additional step they otherwise to do, to go to the Network tab and check the response.
content.formatted_body: by thy way, for ‚ÄúAccess to 'foo' from origin 'bar' has been blocked by CORS policy: Response to preflight request doesn't pass access control check: It does not have HTTP ok status‚Äù, I don‚Äôt understand why that message doesn‚Äôt have ‚ÄúThe HTTP status was 4xx‚Äù ‚Äî that is, just make that message show the actual status code, rather than ‚Äúdoes not have HTTP ok status‚Äù. Knowing the actual status code there would be way more helpful to developers. It would cut out the additional step they otherwise to do, to go to the Network tab and check the response.

content.body: very commonly, a 400 Bad Request
well, but that said, also quite commonly, a 500 or 502
anway, I don‚Äôt understand why browsers can‚Äôt include the exact status code in every CORS errors message ‚Äî or if they can, why they aren‚Äôt doing that
it would especially be more helpful for the error messages for the actual response (not just the preflight)
Well, we don't want to expose it directly to web content as that would violate SOP.
yeah I don‚Äôt mean exposing it to web content
We could expose it to DevTools probably and I think some might do that, but perhaps not to the extent that's desired.
I mean just logging it to the devtools console
Did you file bugs? I think we're pretty open to changing these messages.
well it‚Äôs not a spec issue, right?
it‚Äôs a browser issue
Right, https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/enter_bug.cgi?product=Core üôÇ
OK
yeah I will file bugs
Cool! DOM: Networking is the component for us btw
hai
